00001 /*! \file test-apps
00002     \brief This file is not part of the driver sources.  The contents of this file are used in HTML document generation.
00003 */
00004 
00005 /*! \page test-main OCTEON PCI Host Test Programs
00006 
00007     The PCI base driver package includes sample programs to demonstrate usage of
00008     the input and output queues and the PCI DMA engines of OCTEON using the PCI
00009     driver.
00010 
00011     The following kernel-space applications are available:
00012 
00013     1. req_resp - Provides a linux kernel module that uses the API's exported by
00014     the driver for request processing to send requests to the OCTEON cores. It
00015     requires the cvmcs core application to respond to the requests it sends.
00016 
00017     2. droq_test - Provides a linux kernel module that registers dispatch
00018     functions for a set of pre-defined opcodes. It required the cvmcs core
00019     application to send packets on the PCI output queues with these opcodes.
00020 
00021 
00022     There is also a user-space application:
00023 
00024     1. oct_req - It uses the user api's from the host api library to send
00025     requests to the OCTEON cores. It requires the cvmcs core application to
00026     respond to the requests it sends.
00027 
00028 <br><br><br>
00029     \section core_app Core application (cvmcs)
00030 
00031     All the test programs running on the PCI host require the <b>cvmcs</b> core
00032     application. The sources for this application is located at
00033     OCTEON-SDK/applications/pci-core-app.
00034 
00035     The main initialization routines can be found in pci-core-app/base and
00036     pci-core-app/common. All test routines are available from pci-core-app/test.
00037 
00038     The application can be compiled to perform one or more type of tests at a
00039     given time. The type of tests that the application runs is determined by the
00040     definitions in pci-core-app/test/cvmcs-test.h file.
00041 
00042     By default, the application will process requests with opcode CVMCS_REQRESP_OP.
00043     If a response is required (the rptr field in PCI instruction will be
00044     non-zero), the application copies the input bytes into the output buffers
00045     and sends a response back to the host. If the output buffer is bigger than
00046     the input, it fills the remaining output bytes with a signature value (0xFA
00047     currently).
00048     The host application (either the req_resp kernel application or oct_req
00049     user-space application) can compare the input and output buffer contents to
00050     see if the operation was successful.
00051 
00052     The application also supports scatter mode responses. The cvmcs-reqresp.c
00053     file has routines to read a scatter list in blocking and non-blocking mode
00054     and to send back a scatter response. The application exercises all scatter
00055     mode API depending on the flags enabled in cvmcs-test.h. The source is
00056     well-documented and should be self-explanatory. See the core driver html
00057     documentation for more details on the core driver API.
00058 
00059     The following definitions in cvmcs-test.h enable other functions:
00060 
00061     \li CVMCS_TEST_PKO - Enable this to send test packets on the output queues
00062         with opcodes DROQ_PKT_OP1 and DROQ_PKT_OP2. This option is useful
00063         when running the <b>droq_test</b> kernel space program. The test allows
00064         test to be sequentially increasing upto CMV_MAX_DATA, fixed at
00065         CVM_MAX_DATA or random sizes from 1 to CVM_MAX_DATA for each test packet
00066         send to host via PKO.
00067 
00068 
00069     \li CVM_MAX_DATA - The packets sent to output queue will not be greater
00070         than CVM_MAX_DATA in size.
00071 
00072 
00073     To compile the <b>cvmcs</b> program, do make in 
00074     OCTEON-SDK/applications/pci-core-app/base.
00075     A symbolic link is created from OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/bin
00076     to the core application.
00077 
00078 
00079 <br><br>
00080     \section user_space_app  User space test program
00081 
00082     <b> 1. oct_req - test request/response </b> 
00083 
00084     The user space test program, called <b>oct_req</b>, uses the user space
00085     library api to send RAW PCI instructions to OCTEON. It requires the core
00086     application <b>cvmcs</b> to be running on OCTEON cores for its operation.
00087 
00088     The source for <b>oct_req</b> is at OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/test.
00089 
00090     <b>oct_req</b> can be used to send requests of UNORDERED and NORESPONSE
00091     types. The operations can be blocking or non-blocking. The test parameters
00092     can be modified in the file oct_req.c. The type of request and request mode
00093     can also be specified on the command line. The command line arguments
00094     override any settings made in oct_req.c. The default settings in oct_req.c
00095     is to  send NORESPONSE/NON-BLOCKING type requests in DIRECT DMA mode.
00096 
00097     Command line options:
00098     \li -d : Change the DMA mode to use for the request. Supported values are
00099              "direct", "gather", "scatter" and "scatter_gather".
00100     \li -u : Send requests of UNORDERED response order.
00101     \li -b : Send a blocking mode request.
00102     \li -s : Do not print per-packet messages.
00103     \li -y : Answer "yes" to all prompts.
00104     \li [count] - Number of requests to send. If specified, the test will
00105            attempts to send <b>count</b> requests and stop, else it will 
00106            continue to run till stopped (Press ^C to stop).
00107 
00108     To compile the <b>oct_req</b> program, do make in
00109     OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/test. A symbolic link is created from
00110     OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/bin to the application.
00111 
00112 
00113     How to test:
00114     \verbatim
00115     1. Load the driver and OCTEON application by following the instructions in
00116        OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/README.txt.
00117 
00118     2. Load the test application
00119     cmd> ./oct_req -ubsy   # Starts the test with unordered/blocking requests.
00120 
00121     \endverbatim
00122 
00123 
00124 <br><br><br>
00125     \section kern_space_app  Kernel space test applications
00126 
00127     <b> 1. req_resp - test request/response </b>
00128 
00129     The kernel space test program, <b>req_resp</b>, calls driver API's to send
00130     requests to OCTEON.  It requires the core application <b>cvmcs</b> to be
00131     running on the OCTEON cores for its operation. 
00132 
00133     The source for <b>req_resp</b> is at
00134     OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/test/kernel/req_resp.
00135 
00136     <b>req_resp</b> can be used to send requests of ORDERED, UNORDERED and
00137     NORESPONSE types. It can send requests in both BLOCKING and NON-BLOCKING
00138     mode, though its not recommended to use the UNORDERED/NON-BLOCKING method.
00139     The default setting is to send ORDERED/BLOCKING requests. The test program
00140     provides a good reference to writing kernel mode applications that 
00141     need to interface with the OCTEON PCI driver.
00142 
00143     The setting for the application can be changed in OCTEON_req_resp.c. Each
00144     parameter is documented in this file.
00145 
00146     To compile the <b>req_resp</b> program, do make in
00147     OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/test/kernel/req_resp. A symbolic link is
00148     created from OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/bin to the application.
00149 
00150 
00151 
00152     How to test:
00153     \verbatim
00154     1. Load the driver and OCTEON application by following the instructions in
00155        OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/README.txt.
00156 
00157     2. Load the kernel application
00158     cmd> insmod req_resp.ko
00159 
00160     \endverbatim
00161 
00162 
00163 
00164 <br><br>
00165     <b> 2. droq_test - receive packets from output queue </b>
00166 
00167     The kernel space test program, <b>droq_test</b>, registers dispatch
00168     functions to receive unsolicited packets arriving on the output queues.
00169     The <b>droq_test</b> program requires the <b>cvmcs</b> core application
00170     to be running on the OCTEON cores. The cvmcs application must be compiled
00171     with the CVMCS_TEST_PKO flag enabled.
00172 
00173     The source for <b>droq_test</b> is at
00174     OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/test/kernel/droq_test.
00175 
00176     The core application, when set accordingly, will generate packets with 
00177     opcodes DROQ_PKT_OP1 & DROQ_PKT_OP2, and send on the OCTEON output queue.
00178     The OCTEON PCI driver fetches these packets in its interrupt handler and
00179     looks for a dispatch function for these opcodes. If a function exists,
00180     the packet are sent to the dispatch function, else the packets are
00181     discarded.
00182 
00183     <b>droq_test</b> settings can be modied in the OCTEON_droq_test.c file.
00184     If DROQ_TEST_SEC_OPCODE is enabled, the application registers dispatch
00185     function for opcodes DROQ_PKT_OP1 and DROQ_PKT_OP2 with the driver, else
00186     a dispatch function is registered only for DROQ_PKT_OP1.
00187 
00188 
00189     To compile the <b>droq_test</b> program, do make in
00190     OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/test/kernel/droq_test. A symbolic link is
00191     created from OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/bin to the application.
00192 
00193     How to test:
00194     \verbatim
00195     1. Load the driver and OCTEON application by following the instructions in
00196        OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/README.txt.
00197 
00198     2. Load the kernel application
00199     cmd> insmod droq_test.ko
00200 
00201     \endverbatim
00202 
00203 
00204 */
